questions.text: A research team studying vector-borne diseases is examining the epidemiology of various illnesses in a tropical region. They come across the vector depicted in the photograph provided. This vector is notorious for transmitting several diseases, which have a significant impact on public health. One of the researchers wants to confirm which of the following diseases is NOT typically transmitted by this vector. Considering the vector's species and the endemic diseases it can transmit, which disease should be excluded from the list?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Babesiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Babesiosis is not transmitted by soft ticks but by hard ticks, particularly Ixodes ticks. It is important to differentiate between diseases transmitted by different types of vectors, particularly when studying vector-borne illnesses in tropical regions.

questions.text: A resident in a community medicine program is discussing various health care models with their mentor to better understand how different systems impact patient care and public health. During their discussion, they explore the concept of "Socialized medicine," a term often used to describe a specific type of health care system. Which of the following best defines "Socialized medicine"?

options.label: A
options.text: Health care financed by individual patients out-of-pocket at the point of delivery.

options.label: B
options.text: Health care provided as charity, funded by government resources without direct charges to patients

options.label: C
options.text: Health care provided without direct charge to patients, funded by government taxation and regulated by professional medical groups.

options.label: D
options.text: The combination of social medicine principles with the provision of health care services to improve community health.

questions.correct_answer: C. Health care provided without direct charge to patients, funded by government taxation and regulated by professional medical groups.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Health care provided without direct charge to patients, funded by government taxation and regulated by professional medical groups.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Socialized medicine is a healthcare system in which the government provides healthcare services at no cost to the patient, funded by taxation and regulated by professional medical groups. It is designed to ensure health equity and eliminate competition between private practitioners.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ First Country Honours
  • ➤ First country to socialize medicine completely: Russia First country to introduce compulsory sickness insurance: Germany First country to start family planning programme: India First country to start blindness control programme: India First country to establish finger printing bureau: India (Calcutta, 1897)
  • ➤ First country to socialize medicine completely: Russia
  • ➤ First country to introduce compulsory sickness insurance: Germany
  • ➤ First country to start family planning programme: India
  • ➤ First country to start blindness control programme: India
  • ➤ First country to establish finger printing bureau: India (Calcutta, 1897)

questions.text: During a public health rotation in India, a medical student learns about local regulations for vital events. What is the required timeframe for registering a death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 21 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A death in India must be registered within 21 days to comply with legal requirements. This ensures proper documentation and timely issuance of death certificates, which are crucial for legal and administrative purposes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents to her obstetrician after being exposed to a confirmed case of rubella. She is concerned about the risk to her unborn child and inquires about post-exposure prophylaxis. Her obstetrician discusses the option of administering rubella immunoglobulin to reduce the risk of contracting the infection. What is the recommended dose of rubella immunoglobulin for post-exposure prophylaxis in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 20 mL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommended dose of rubella immunoglobulin for post-exposure prophylaxis in pregnant women is 20 mL. This measure is crucial in preventing rubella infection during pregnancy and reducing the risk of congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of fever, headache, and a diffuse maculopapular rash. He has recently returned from a trip to Japan where he participated in outdoor activities. Physical examination reveals an eschar on his right ankle and generalized lymphadenopathy. Laboratory findings show a normal leukocyte count but elevated liver transaminases. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of his clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orientia tsutsugamushi

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orientia tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus, characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, eschar, and elevated liver enzymes. It is transmitted by Trombiculid mites and is endemic to parts of Asia, including Japan.

questions.text: A hospital administrator is trying to optimize the utilization of health services. He aims to strike a balance such that the hospital beds are neither over-utilized nor underutilized. This can be gauged through the bed turnover interval, which measures the amount of time beds in a hospital are unoccupied until the next patient's admission following a patient's discharge. To achieve optimum utilization of health services in the hospital, the bed turnover interval should ideally be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Slightly positive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bed turnover interval should ideally be slightly positive to ensure efficient utilization of hospital beds, allowing enough time for bed preparation while minimizing resource wastage or bed shortages.
  • ➤ slightly positive

questions.text: In the planning phase of a public health intervention in a low-income country, a team of health policy analysts aims to select a primary health indicator that would most effectively reflect both the general health status of the population and the efficiency of health service delivery and utilization within the community. Considering the need for an indicator that is sensitive to both healthcare quality and accessibility, as well as broader socio-economic factors, which of the following would serve as the best measure for the team's objectives?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Infant Mortality Rate (IMR)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is the most sensitive and effective primary health indicator for reflecting both the general health status of the population and the efficiency of healthcare services in low-income countries, as it encompasses both healthcare quality and broader socio-economic factors.
  • ➤ Infant Mortality Rate (IMR)
  • ➤ Remember –
  • ➤ IMR is indicator of –
  • ➤ State Failure Health status of a Country Health service availability/ utilization/ effectiveness Best indicator of ASHA worker performance
  • ➤ State Failure
  • ➤ Health status of a Country
  • ➤ Health service availability/ utilization/ effectiveness
  • ➤ Best indicator of ASHA worker performance
  • ➤ Best indicator of socioeconomic development of a country – U5MR
  • ➤ Best indicator of Virulence or killing power of a disease – CFR
  • ➤ Best indicator of communicability or infectivity – SAR
  • ➤ Best indicator of disease burden – DALY
  • ➤ Best indicator of Cost Effectiveness analysis – QALY
  • ➤ Best indicator of Malaria Control – API (Annual Parasitic Incidence)
  • ➤ Best indicator of Operational Efficiency in Malaria – ABER
  • ➤ Measure of Endemicity of Malaria – Spleen Rate
  • ➤ Measure of Recent transmission of Malaria - Infant Parasite Rate
  • ➤ Measure of TB control in Society – ARI (Annual Risk of Infection)

questions.text: A third-year medical student is preparing a presentation on the history and development of modern medical practices. While researching, the student discovers the concept of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM), a systematic approach to clinical problem-solving which allows the integration of the best available research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values. Intrigued by the transformative impact of EBM on healthcare, the student seeks to acknowledge the pioneer of this approach in their presentation. Who is recognized as the father of Evidence-Based Medicine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sackett

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Father of Evidence based Medicine - DL Sackett Father of Epidemiology/Modern Epidemiology, Greatest doctor - John Snow Father of Public health – Cholera Father of Medicine/Modern medicine, First True Epidemiologist – Hippocrates First Distinguished Epidemiologist – Sydenham
  • ➤ Father of Evidence based Medicine - DL Sackett
  • ➤ Father of Epidemiology/Modern Epidemiology, Greatest doctor - John Snow
  • ➤ Father of Public health – Cholera
  • ➤ Father of Medicine/Modern medicine, First True Epidemiologist – Hippocrates
  • ➤ First Distinguished Epidemiologist – Sydenham

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of easy bruising and delayed wound healing presents to her primary care physician. She follows a strict diet due to personal preferences, which primarily excludes fruits and certain vegetables. On further dietary assessment, the physician suspects a nutritional deficiency that might be contributing to her symptoms. Considering the crucial role of certain micronutrients in collagen synthesis, which of the following combinations is most likely deficient in this patient's diet?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ascorbic Acid and Copper

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) and copper are vital for collagen synthesis and the maintenance of connective tissue. Deficiencies in these micronutrients can lead to symptoms such as easy bruising, poor wound healing, and gum bleeding, which are hallmark features of scurvy .
  • ➤ Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)
  • ➤ copper
  • ➤ scurvy

questions.text: A public health department is evaluating the effectiveness of a recent mass gathering organized to promote handwashing awareness among a rural population with historically high rates of infectious diseases transmitted through fecal-oral routes. The event included educational presentations, demonstrations of proper handwashing techniques, and distribution of free hygiene kits. The department aims to understand the logical sequence of cognitive and behavioural changes in the community post-event. Which of the following sequences best describes the expected progression from awareness to practice change in this context?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Awareness → Interest → Evaluation → Adoption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In public health interventions aimed at behavior change, the typical progression from awareness to practice involves: Awareness (learning about the issue), Interest (curiosity about how it works), Evaluation (assessing its relevance and feasibility), and finally Adoption (implementing the behavior).
  • ➤ Awareness
  • ➤ Interest
  • ➤ Evaluation
  • ➤ Adoption

questions.text: A 35-year-old public health researcher discusses the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) during a seminar. The PQLI includes various indicators to assess health status. Which components does the PQLI consider? Expectancy of life at birth Expectancy of life at age one Infant mortality rate Literacy rate

options.label: B
options.text: I, III and IV are correct

options.label: C
options.text: I, II and III are correct

options.label: D
options.text: II, III and IV are correct

questions.correct_answer: D. II, III and IV are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) II, III and IV are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) includes life expectancy at age one, infant mortality rate, and literacy rate as its components, offering a simple and effective measure of a population’s well-being, focusing on public health and basic human needs.
  • ➤ Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)

questions.text: In the "Iceberg Phenomenon" of epidemiology, which illustrates the visible and hidden aspects of disease, which option does not represent the submerged, unseen portion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diagnosed cases under treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the "Iceberg Phenomenon," diagnosed cases under treatment are the visible, apparent portion, while undetected, pre-symptomatic, and subclinical cases form the submerged, unseen part. This model highlights the importance of considering undiagnosed cases in public health interventions.
  • ➤ diagnosed cases under treatment
  • ➤ undetected, pre-symptomatic, and subclinical cases

questions.text: A 50-year-old historian is researching the impact of medical advancements on society. He notes a significant shift in the leading causes of mortality from infectious to chronic diseases over the past century. This observation is crucial for understanding how public health strategies have evolved. What term best describes this shift in disease prevalence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Epidemiological transition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The term epidemiological transition best describes the shift in the leading causes of mortality from infectious to chronic diseases, a trend observed in more developed countries as public health strategies improve over time.
  • ➤ epidemiological transition

questions.text: HDI does not include?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IMR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Human Development Index (HDI) includes longevity , standard of living , and knowledge but does not include infant mortality rate (IMR) .
  • ➤ Human Development Index (HDI)
  • ➤ longevity
  • ➤ standard of living
  • ➤ knowledge
  • ➤ not include infant mortality rate (IMR)

questions.text: In a hospital laboratory setting, proper disposal of medical waste is paramount to ensuring safety and preventing contamination. A new laboratory technician is being trained on the protocols for disposing of various types of laboratory waste, including used vacutainers, which are commonly used for blood collection. The technician learns that different colors of disposal containers and bags are designated for specific types of waste according to standard biomedical waste management guidelines. Based on these guidelines, in which of the following disposal containers should used vacutainers be discarded?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Red bag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Used vacutainers that are not sharps but have been used for blood collection should be discarded in the red bag , following biomedical waste management guidelines. Proper segregation of medical waste is essential for maintaining safety and hygiene in healthcare settings.
  • ➤ Used vacutainers
  • ➤ red bag

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the incubation periods of various sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Match the following STIs to their respective incubation periods:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-C, 3-E, 4-B, 5-A, 6-F

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Barometer of Social Welfare is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) TB Tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuberculosis (TB) serves as a "barometer of social welfare" because its prevalence is heavily influenced by social determinants like poverty, malnutrition, and access to healthcare.
  • ➤ Tuberculosis (TB)
  • ➤ Remember –
  • ➤ Remember
  • ➤ White death / White Plague - TB American Plague – Yellow Fever Monkey disease – KFD Cerebrospinal Fever – Meningococcal meningitis Black Sickness: Kala Azar (Leishmaniasis) Black Death: Plague Slim’s Disease - HIV
  • ➤ White death / White Plague - TB
  • ➤ American Plague – Yellow Fever
  • ➤ Monkey disease – KFD
  • ➤ Cerebrospinal Fever – Meningococcal meningitis
  • ➤ Black Sickness: Kala Azar (Leishmaniasis)
  • ➤ Black Death: Plague
  • ➤ Slim’s Disease - HIV

questions.text: In a community health clinic, a Senior resident is educating a group of interns about different types of vaccines and their mechanisms of action. The SR explains that some vaccines contain live, weakened forms of the pathogens, while others contain inactivated or killed versions. Which of the following is an inactivated vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Salk polio vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Salk polio vaccine is an inactivated (killed) vaccine, while vaccines like Ty21a , HDC-Edmonston-Zagreb , and BCG are live attenuated vaccines. Inactivated vaccines require more doses, but they are safer for immunocompromised individuals since they cannot replicate in the body.
  • ➤ Salk polio vaccine
  • ➤ Ty21a
  • ➤ HDC-Edmonston-Zagreb
  • ➤ BCG
  • ➤ Remember –
  • ➤ Lyophilized Vaccine – BCG, Measles (Edmonston Zagreb), Yellow Fever

questions.text: During a pediatric immunization clinic, a healthcare provider is discussing vaccine efficacy and potential reasons for vaccine failure with a group of parents. The provider emphasizes the importance of proper vaccine storage, administration, and manufacturing to ensure effectiveness. To assess understanding, the provider presents a multiple-choice question to the parents regarding the most common cause of vaccine failure. Most common cause of Vaccine failure is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Maternally derived antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maternally derived antibodies are the most common cause of primary vaccine failure in infants, particularly affecting live attenuated vaccines by neutralizing the vaccine antigen before an immune response can be developed.
  • ➤ Maternally derived antibodies
  • ➤ Remember –
  • ➤ MC cause of Primary vaccination failure - Maternally derived antibodies MC cause of secondary Vaccination failure – Waning immunity
  • ➤ MC cause of Primary vaccination failure - Maternally derived antibodies
  • ➤ MC cause of secondary Vaccination failure – Waning immunity

questions.text: At a primary healthcare center, a 3-year-old child presents for their first immunization appointment, having never received any vaccinations before. The healthcare provider discusses the importance of starting the child's vaccination schedule to protect against preventable diseases. Which combination of vaccines and supplements should the child receive during this visit?

options.label: C
options.text: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vitamin A

questions.correct_answer: D. DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vitamin A
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles, Vitamin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a 3-year-old child presenting for their first immunization, the correct vaccines to be given include DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles , and Vitamin A supplementation . BCG is not given after 1 year of age, and all vaccines should be administered according to the delayed immunization schedule.
  • ➤ 3-year-old child
  • ➤ DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles
  • ➤ Vitamin A supplementation

questions.text: A 28-year-old public health researcher in Pune, India, is deeply engrossed in studying the repercussions of a recent viral outbreak in a nearby suburban locality. The viral infection manifests as severe respiratory symptoms and, intriguingly, results in protracted fatigue in a subset of afflicted patients. Keen on understanding the dual implications of this outbreak - both in terms of premature mortality and the diminution in quality of life due to persisting symptoms - the researcher seeks an apt metric. Which of the following metrics would best encapsulate the collective impact of premature mortality and quality of life decrements stemming from this viral outbreak?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) is the most appropriate metric for capturing both premature mortality and the impact of diminished quality of life due to disease or disability. It is widely used to assess disease burden in public health.
  • ➤ Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY)

questions.text: In a research study examining the association between alcohol consumption and liver cirrhosis, 45 out of 100 patients with liver cirrhosis were found to be regular drinkers, compared to 15 out of 100 control subjects. What is the odds ratio of liver cirrhosis associated with regular alcohol consumption?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4.6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ odds ratio is a measure of association in a case-control study that compares the odds of exposure in cases (with the disease) to the odds of exposure in controls (without the disease). In this example, the odds ratio of 4.6 means that patients with liver cirrhosis are 4.6 times more likely to have a history of regular alcohol consumption compared to healthy individuals.
  • ➤ odds ratio
  • ➤ 4.6

questions.text: Considering the demographic data provided for tribal populations, which aspect highlights a significant health concern among these communities?

options.label: A
options.text: A predominant urban residency pattern among tribal populations.

options.label: B
options.text: A pronounced gender disparity in literacy rates favoring females within tribal communities.

options.label: C
options.text: Higher life expectancy among tribal populations in Odisha compared to those in Madhya Pradesh.

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated infant mortality rate (IMR) in tribal populations compared to the national average.

questions.correct_answer: D. Elevated infant mortality rate (IMR) in tribal populations compared to the national average.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Elevated infant mortality rate (IMR) in tribal populations compared to the national average.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that the infant mortality rate (IMR) is one of the most important indicators of the health status of a community. A higher IMR, as seen in many tribal populations, reflects serious health concerns, including poor access to healthcare and high vulnerability of children to preventable diseases.
  • ➤ infant mortality rate (IMR)

questions.text: In a recent seminar on improving healthcare efficiency using statistical methodologies, Dr. Vikram Joshi, a renowned health systems researcher, delves into a technique that's rooted in stochastic processes. This particular method facilitates the systematic observation and quantification of specific tasks or activities undertaken by healthcare professionals, for example, doctors, nurses, etc. By collecting data either at set deterministic intervals or based on a probabilistic approach, this technique assists in estimating the distribution of time across various tasks, ultimately providing insights into work patterns, resource allocation, and potential bottlenecks within a healthcare system. Which statistical methodology is Dr. Joshi referring to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Work sampling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Work sampling is a statistical methodology used to observe and quantify the time healthcare professionals spend on various tasks, providing insights into work patterns, resource allocation, and potential bottlenecks within the system. It is a valuable tool for improving healthcare efficiency.
  • ➤ Work sampling

questions.text: Dr. Ayesha Gupta, an emergency medicine specialist, is conducting a training session for first responders on mass casualty incidents. She emphasizes the importance of a specific triage system that rapidly assesses victims based on their ability to walk, respiratory status, perfusion, and mental function. This system prioritizes patients based on the severity of their injuries to ensure that those who are most likely to survive with immediate treatment are attended to first, which is known as START Triage. What is the correct full form of START?
questions.correct_answer: C. Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ START (Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment) is a triage system designed for mass casualty situations. It enables rapid classification of patients based on the severity of their condition, helping prioritize those who can benefit most from immediate medical intervention.
  • ➤ START (Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment)

questions.text: Match the following pieces of legislation with their respective years of enactment:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Familiarize oneself with significant pieces of Indian legislation and their years of enactment. This helps in understanding the legal framework around public health, safety, and protection of rights in India.

questions.text: Review and evaluate the differences between case-control studies and cohort studies to understand their unique characteristics and appropriate applications. Which of the following statements about the differences between case-control and cohort studies is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: A case-control study is typically more time-consuming to conduct compared to a cohort study.

options.label: B
options.text: In a cohort study, participants are selected based on their exposure status to determine the effect of the exposure on the development of disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Cohort studies are usually prospective, following participants over time to observe the occurrence of disease outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: Case-control studies are particularly useful for investigating rare diseases because they start with cases that have the disease of interest.

questions.correct_answer: A. A case-control study is typically more time-consuming to conduct compared to a cohort study.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A case-control study is typically more time-consuming to conduct compared to a cohort study.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The main point to understand here is the distinction between case-control and cohort studies :
  • ➤ case-control
  • ➤ cohort studies
  • ➤ Case-control studies are retrospective, quick, cost-effective, and ideal for studying rare diseases. Cohort studies are often prospective, focusing on following participants based on exposure status to assess disease development over time. These studies are more time-consuming but provide stronger evidence for causality.
  • ➤ Case-control studies are retrospective, quick, cost-effective, and ideal for studying rare diseases.
  • ➤ Case-control studies
  • ➤ Cohort studies are often prospective, focusing on following participants based on exposure status to assess disease development over time. These studies are more time-consuming but provide stronger evidence for causality.
  • ➤ Cohort studies

questions.text: In a case conference on toxicology held in Kolkata, Dr. Neha Basu describes a series of patients suffering from alarming symptoms: bilateral pitting edema, signs of gastroenteritis, and striking ocular issues. The extensive investigative work revealed a shared dietary exposure among these patients: they all consumed a particular type of mustard oil brought from a single grocery store. Dr. Basu posits that a specific compound, known to contaminate mustard oil, was the trigger behind these symptoms, a scenario leading to the alarming clinical picture. Which of the following compounds is most likely responsible for this outbreak?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sanguinarine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to memorize is that epidemic dropsy is caused by consumption of mustard oil contaminated with Argemone oil , which contains the toxic compound sanguinarine . This leads to symptoms like bilateral pitting edema, gastroenteritis, and ocular issues, and is a serious public health concern related to food adulteration.
  • ➤ epidemic dropsy
  • ➤ Argemone oil
  • ➤ sanguinarine

questions.text: A community medicine resident, is reviewing potential adverse effects of vaccines during her thesis study. She focuses on the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) and recalls a specific rare but serious side effect known as Vaccine-Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP). She understands that knowing the typical onset time of VAPP following OPV administration is crucial for clinical vigilance and parent counselling. How many days after OPV administration does VAPP typically develop?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 7–14

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key point to remember is that Vaccine-Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP) typically occurs 7 to 14 days after OPV administration. This timeframe is important for clinicians to understand for the purposes of clinical vigilance and advising parents regarding possible adverse effects.
  • ➤ Vaccine-Associated Paralytic Poliomyelitis (VAPP)
  • ➤ 7 to 14 days

questions.text: A 3 rd year medical student is studying the dynamics of disease transmission and the significance of various epidemiological terms. He understands that precise definitions are crucial for interpreting outbreak data and planning public health interventions. He comes across a term describing the time taken for 50% of exposed individuals to develop a disease and wants to ensure his understanding is accurate. Which term correctly defines the time taken for 50% of patients to develop the disease following exposure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Median incubation period

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key concept here is that the median incubation period defines the time by which 50% of exposed individuals will have developed the disease. This measure is important for epidemiologists when assessing the progression of an outbreak and the timeline for symptom onset in a population.
  • ➤ median incubation period

questions.text: In a community health posting, Dr. Sharma, a final-year medical student in India, is tasked with investigating an outbreak of an unknown disease in a rural area. She recalls the Bradford Hill criteria for causal inference, which she learned during her preventive and social medicine lectures. Dr. Sharma is aware that establishing a causal relationship between a potential risk factor and the disease is crucial for effective intervention. Among the Bradford Hill criteria, which does she recognize as particularly challenging to establish in the context of the disease's etiology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Specificity of association

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key takeaway is that specificity of association is often the most challenging to establish among the Bradford Hill criteria for causality. Most diseases have multiple causes or can be linked to various factors, making it less relevant and difficult to meet this criterion in many cases. On the other hand, temporality is crucial and must always be established to prove causality.
  • ➤ specificity of association
  • ➤ temporality

questions.text: In a research methodology, Dr. Anand discusses the principles of clinical trials with his students. He emphasizes the importance of randomization and presents a question to test their understanding: "Which of the following is not a direct benefit of randomization in clinical trials?"
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enhances external validity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Randomization is essential for minimizing selection bias and ensuring comparability between groups in clinical trials. However, it does not directly enhance external validity (generalizability). External validity is influenced by how well the study population and settings reflect real-world conditions, not by randomization alone.
  • ➤ external validity

questions.text: Dr. Lakshmi Iyer, a renowned social economist from Chennai, is addressing a seminar on innovative measures for understanding country dynamics. She emphasized a particular index that evaluates the country based on multiple facets, rather than solely relying on income per capita. This index factors in aspects like deprivation in health, education, and living standards to provide a more comprehensive assessment. Which index is Dr. Iyer referring to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) provides a more nuanced assessment of poverty by evaluating deprivation across multiple domains, such as health, education, and living standards. This approach allows policymakers to better understand and address the root causes of poverty beyond just income levels.
  • ➤ Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)

questions.text: At an epidemiology conference in Toronto, Dr. Arjun Singh, an esteemed epidemiologist, showcased a compelling longitudinal study. In his study, 45,000 men were diligently monitored over 25 years, of which 2,500 developed prostate cancer. In an attempt to enhance the depth of the study, an additional 3,500 men confirmed to be healthy were included as controls. Dr. Singh highlighted that at the start of the study, potential risk factors were deduced from baseline data gathered through questionnaires disseminated to both sets of participants along with their blood samples which were stored after proper labelling. This strategic approach was designed to trace the onset of disease over an extended period, subsequently analysing it with the baseline data. Which terminology best describes this study design?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nested case-control study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key takeaway is that a nested case-control study is a type of cohort study where a case-control analysis is conducted within a previously established cohort. It maintains the temporal advantage of cohort studies (exposure before outcome) and is cost-efficient by only studying a subset of cases and controls from the larger cohort.
  • ➤ nested case-control study

questions.text: During a clinical research session, Dr. Khan presents a case study involving a new diagnostic test for a particular medical condition. The test was administered to a population of 10,000 individuals, with 500 known to have the condition. The test produced 350 true positive results and 1900 false positive results. Dr. Khan asks the students to identify the accurate statements regarding the test. Which of the following statements about the diagnostic test are true? Prevalence is 5% Sensitivity is 70% Specificity is 80% Sensitivity is 80% Specificity is 70%
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To calculate key diagnostic test parameters—such as sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence—is essential in interpreting the effectiveness and reliability of medical tests. Sensitivity focuses on identifying true positives, while specificity measures the accuracy in detecting true negatives.

questions.text: A physician is reviewing the mortality rates of various infectious diseases with a group of medical students during rounds. Which of the following diseases is associated with the highest mortality rate after clinical manifestations develop?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key point is that rabies has the highest mortality rate of all these diseases once symptoms have developed. This highlights the importance of prevention (vaccination) and immediate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies to prevent the disease from progressing to its fatal stage.
  • ➤ rabies

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing congenital rubella with a group of medical residents during a morning report session. She presents the following scenario: "A 2-week-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The mother reports having rubella infection during pregnancy. On examination, the infant appears healthy. Laboratory tests reveal the presence of IgM antibodies in the infant's blood." Which of the following statements regarding congenital rubella is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Diagnosis of congenital rubella is confirmed by the presence of IgM antibodies in the infant's blood at birth.

options.label: B
options.text: Diagnosis of congenital rubella is confirmed when IgG antibodies persist for more than 6 months in the infant's blood.

options.label: C
options.text: The most common congenital defects associated with congenital rubella include deafness, cardiac malformations, and cataracts.

options.label: D
options.text: Rubella infection occurring after 16 weeks of gestation can result in major congenital defects.

questions.correct_answer: D. Rubella infection occurring after 16 weeks of gestation can result in major congenital defects.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rubella infection occurring after 16 weeks of gestation can result in major congenital defects.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubella infection before 16 weeks of gestation carries the highest risk of serious congenital defects, while infections occurring later in pregnancy are less likely to cause major anomalies. However, the presence of specific antibodies (IgM at birth and persistent IgG) plays a crucial role in diagnosing congenital rubella.
  • ➤ Rubella infection before 16 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A public health official is tasked with assessing the prevalence of tuberculosis infection in a community. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tuberculin test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tuberculin test is the most suitable tool for assessing the prevalence of TB infection (both latent and active) in a community. It helps to determine whether individuals have been exposed to Mycobacterium tuberculosis at some point. It is important to distinguish between infection and active disease , as other tests like sputum smear or radiography are more appropriate for diagnosing active TB cases.
  • ➤ tuberculin test
  • ➤ infection
  • ➤ infection
  • ➤ active disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department with fever and swelling of the lower limbs. Upon examination, he tests positive for Filarial antigen. Considering his clinical presentation, which diagnostic test would be most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis of filariasis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Peripheral blood smear (PBS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For diagnosing lymphatic filariasis , the peripheral blood smear is the primary diagnostic test. Blood samples should be taken at night (8:30 pm to midnight) due to the nocturnal periodicity of microfilariae. In cases where microfilariae are not detected in the blood smear, a DEC provocation test may be used as a follow-up diagnostic tool.
  • ➤ lymphatic filariasis
  • ➤ peripheral blood smear
  • ➤ DEC provocation test

questions.text: In efforts to combat the spread of Yellow Fever, identification and containment are crucial. Which institution serves as the designated reference center for Yellow Fever?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Central Institute, Kasauli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Central Research Institute (CRI), Kasauli , is the designated center for Yellow Fever in India, responsible for vaccination and surveillance related to the disease.
  • ➤ Central Research Institute (CRI), Kasauli

questions.text: The "MONICA Project" is a comprehensive endeavor aimed at understanding and tracking specific aspects of a prevalent health concern. Which of the following options best describes the focus of the MONICA Project?

options.label: A
options.text: Investigating interventions to mitigate cardiovascular disease risks

options.label: B
options.text: Studying the effects of diet and smoking on health outcomes

options.label: C
options.text: Systematically monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease

options.label: D
options.text: Conducting research on lipid profiles and their impact on health

questions.correct_answer: C. Systematically monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Systematically monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The MONICA Project was an international collaboration aimed at systematically monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease across various countries.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a weight of 89 kg and a height of 172 cm. As part of his routine health assessment, you are tasked with calculating his Body Mass Index (BMI). BMI is a measure used to assess the relationship between weight and height, indicating potential health risks associated with body composition. Which of the following options corresponds to the calculated BMI?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 30

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision and sustains multiple injuries. He is rushed to the hospital and receives immediate medical attention. Despite initial improvements, his condition deteriorates, and he passes away a few weeks after the accident. According to standard classifications, a death is attributed to a road traffic accident if it occurs within a certain number of days post-incident. Based on this criterion, if the man dies within how many days of the accident would his death be classified as a road traffic accident fatality?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 30 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Death is classified as a road traffic accident fatality if it occurs within 30 days of the incident. This time frame is crucial for attributing fatalities directly to motor vehicle accidents.
  • ➤ 30 days

questions.text: During a routine health consultation, a patient asks about the risks associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Which of the following conditions is HPV known to cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should remember that HPV infection is linked to a wide range of cancers, including cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal cancers , among others. HPV types 16 and 18 are the most significant high-risk strains associated with these cancers, while types 6 and 11 cause genital warts and laryngeal papillomatosis. The HPV vaccine is recommended for both males and females to prevent these conditions.
  • ➤ cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal cancers
  • ➤ HPV vaccine

questions.text: A healthcare policy analyst is reviewing the priorities for eye health initiatives in India. They examine the major causes of blindness and visual impairment to align with the goals of Vision 2020. Based on prevalent eye health issues in the country, which of the following conditions is least likely to be a primary concern for Vision 2020 in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Onchocerciasis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should remember that onchocerciasis (river blindness) is not a concern in India because the black fly vector does not exist in the country. In contrast, conditions like cataract, glaucoma , and diabetic retinopathy are significant priorities for Vision 2020 in India.
  • ➤ onchocerciasis (river blindness)
  • ➤ cataract, glaucoma
  • ➤ diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating strategies for the prevention of infectious diseases within a community. Considering the epidemiological characteristics and modes of transmission of various diseases, chemoprophylaxis might not be practical for some diseases. Which of the following diseases is chemoprophylaxis most impractical for controlling, due to these reasons? Measles Cholera Diphtheria Tuberculosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chemoprophylaxis is impractical for diseases like measles and tuberculosis for population-wide prevention, as vaccination (measles) or targeted treatment (TB in high-risk individuals) are more effective and feasible approaches.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the general OPD with a prolonged fever, substantial weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly. After a thorough investigation, he is diagnosed with visceral leishmaniasis, commonly known as Kala-azar. The physician decides to follow the national treatment guidelines for this condition. Based on the Indian treatment program for Kala-azar, what is the drug of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) LAMB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liposomal Amphotericin B (LAMB) is the drug of choice for treating visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar) in India. Sodium Stibogluconate was previously used but is no longer the preferred treatment due to safety and efficacy concerns.
  • ➤ Liposomal Amphotericin B (LAMB)

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with fever, migrating joint pain, and a recent history of sore throat. On examination, a heart murmur suggestive of valvular disease is noted. Given the clinical picture suggestive of rheumatic fever, which public health initiative could most effectively contribute to the control of this condition and its sequelae, including rheumatic heart disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Jai Vigyan Mission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Jai Vigyan Mission is a public health initiative focused on studying and controlling rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease in India. It emphasizes epidemiological research, registry creation, and the development of potential preventive measures like vaccines.
  • ➤ Jai Vigyan Mission

questions.text: In order to gather updated information on immunization rates within a community, public health officials rely on various data collection methods. Which of the following sources is most directly aligned with obtaining detailed, recent data on immunization trends at a community level?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) District Level Household Survey (DLHS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should remember that the District Level Household Survey (DLHS) is the most reliable source for collecting detailed, updated data on immunization trends at both the community and district levels.
  • ➤ District Level Household Survey (DLHS)
  • ➤ immunization trends

questions.text: As a program manager improving ASHA workers' performance, you're assessing the impact of your interventions. Considering their diverse roles, which indicator most accurately reflects the success of these initiatives in the community?

options.label: D
options.text: Training hours completed by ASHA workers

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decline in infant mortality

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decline in infant mortality (IMR) is the most comprehensive indicator of the success of healthcare interventions led by ASHA workers, as it reflects improvements in maternal and child health services and overall community health outcomes.
  • ➤ Decline in infant mortality

questions.text: As part of a global initiative, you're implementing the WHO STEPwise approach for Non-communicable Disease (NCD) surveillance in your state. The approach is designed to systematically collect and analyze data on NCD risk factors through a series of steps. Which of the following statements incorrectly describes a component of the WHO STEPwise approach?

options.label: A
options.text: STEP 1 involves conducting interviews to gather essential data.

options.label: B
options.text: STEP 2 entails measuring blood pressure and performing anthropometric assessments.

options.label: C
options.text: STEP 3 involves collecting blood samples to measure blood glucose and cholesterol levels.

options.label: D
options.text: STEP 4 focuses on the treatment of identified NCDs.

questions.correct_answer: D. STEP 4 focuses on the treatment of identified NCDs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) STEP 4 focuses on the treatment of identified NCDs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO STEPwise approach is a surveillance tool for monitoring NCD risk factors through behavioral, physical, and biochemical assessments. There is no "STEP 4" for treatment, as treatment is not part of the surveillance process.
  • ➤ WHO STEPwise approach

questions.text: In reviewing the historical data collection efforts on disability in India, a researcher is analyzing the inception of disability-specific census activities. Given the long history of census-taking in the country, identifying the first year when disabilities were explicitly included provides insights into the evolving recognition of disability issues. In which year did India conduct its first census that included data on disabilities?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1881

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 1881 Census was the first census in India to include data on disabilities. This was an important early step in recognizing and documenting disability issues in the country.
  • ➤ 1881 Census
  • ➤ Remember - 2024 – 16 th census of India

questions.text: A public health official is analyzing demographic data to understand the fertility patterns within a specific population. What does the TFR specifically indicate in the context of population studies?

options.label: A
options.text: The average age of women at first childbirth

options.label: B
options.text: The total number of children born to a woman by the end of her reproductive life

options.label: C
options.text: The ratio of male to female births in a given population

options.label: D
options.text: The percentage of women in the reproductive age group within the total population

questions.correct_answer: B. The total number of children born to a woman by the end of her reproductive life
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The total number of children born to a woman by the end of her reproductive life

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TFR refers to the total number of children born to a woman over her reproductive life . It is a key measure in demographic studies for understanding fertility patterns and population growth trends.
  • ➤ TFR
  • ➤ total number of children born to a woman over her reproductive life
  • ➤ Note –
  • ➤ TFR (India) – 2.0
  • ➤ NRR ( India) – 1.0
  • ➤ CPR (India) – 67%
  • ➤ Crude Birth rate = (8TFR) + 1

questions.text: Match the contraceptive methods listed in Column A with the correct failure rates in Column B:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methods like vasectomy have the lowest failure rates, while methods like the female condom and vaginal sponge have higher variability in effectiveness based on user consistency and correct usage.
  • ➤ vasectomy
  • ➤ female condom
  • ➤ vaginal sponge

questions.text: In demographic studies, various rates are used to understand population dynamics. Among the following mention rates which includes the mortality in calculation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) NRR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is the demographic measure that incorporates mortality in its calculation, while TFR and GRR do not account for mortality.
  • ➤ Net Reproduction Rate (NRR)
  • ➤ mortality

questions.text: In a study on population dynamics, a demographer evaluates Community X to understand its economic sustainability. The community's age distribution reveals that 30% are under 15 years of age and 10% are older than 65. To gauge the potential economic pressure on the working-age population, the demographer decides to calculate the community's dependency ratio. Based on this age distribution, what is the calculated dependency ratio for Community X?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 66.6%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that the dependency ratio reflects the ratio of non-working individuals to working-age individuals, expressed as a percentage. It provides insight into the economic sustainability of a community by showing how many non-working individuals depend on each 100 working individuals for support.
  • ➤ dependency ratio

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a follow-up visit after having an intrauterine device (IUD) inserted as a contraceptive method one month ago. She reports experiencing a significant side effect since the insertion. Based on the most common side effects associated with IUDs, which of the following is she most likely to report?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bleeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bleeding is the most common side effect associated with IUD use, especially within the first few months after insertion. It is generally managed with reassurance and iron supplementation unless it persists beyond a couple of menstrual cycles.
  • ➤ Bleeding

questions.text: In the study of population dynamics, 'demographic processes' encompass several key components that drive changes in population size and structure. Which of the following is NOT considered a core component of demographic processes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Morbidity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that morbidity is not considered a core component of demographic processes. The primary drivers of demographic change are fertility, mortality, migration, and to some extent, marriage .
  • ➤ morbidity
  • ➤ fertility, mortality, migration,
  • ➤ marriage

questions.text: As a Block Medical Officer in a rural CHC, you are evaluating the performance of one of your subcenter, focusing on maternal care services. The subcenter serves a population where the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) is estimated to be 20 per 1,000 individuals annually. To ensure adequate prenatal care, your aim is to assess if the expected number of pregnancies is being registered with the ANM at the subcenter. What is the minimum expected number of pregnancies that should be registered with the ANM, assuming the subcenter caters to a standard population size?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 55

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that in maternal health services, calculating the expected number of pregnancies in a population involves using the Crude Birth Rate and adjusting for pregnancy wastage. According to government guidelines, at least 50% of the expected pregnancies should be registered with the ANM at a subcenter for effective prenatal care.

questions.text: A rural healthcare facility recorded 4050 births in a year within their service area. Among these births, 50 were stillborn. Furthermore, 50 neonates passed away within the initial 7 days of life, while an additional 150 neonates passed away between the 8th and 28th days of life. What is the Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) for this rural population?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 50

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To calculate the Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR), use the formula: the number of neonatal deaths (within the first 28 days of life) divided by the number of live births, multiplied by 1,000. Remember to exclude stillbirths from live births when calculating NMR.

questions.text: A Medical Officer is reviewing the properties of breast milk. Which of the following statements regarding breast milk is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum output is at 12 months of lactation

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium utilization is higher than cow's milk

options.label: D
options.text: Breast milk contains high amounts of lactose

questions.correct_answer: A. Maximum output is at 12 months of lactation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Maximum output is at 12 months of lactation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast milk provides essential nutrients with high bioavailability, including iron and calcium. The maximum milk output is achieved around the 5th to 6th month of lactation, and lactose content is high in breast milk, which aids in the infant's growth and gut health.

questions.text: A 35-year-old nutritionist is conducting a research study to determine the most effective method for evaluating the quality of proteins in various food sources. She aims to understand how well the body can utilize these proteins based on their composition and how they are absorbed and retained in the body. Considering the comprehensive nature of the assessment, which method should she focus on to obtain a more complete evaluation of protein quality?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Net protein utilization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Net Protein Utilization (NPU) is the most comprehensive method for evaluating protein quality because it combines both the digestibility of the protein and its biological value, offering a complete picture of how well the body can absorb and retain the protein.
  • ➤ Net Protein Utilization (NPU)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of poor wound healing, erythematous scaly pustular lesions concentrated around the mouth, and persistent diarrhea. The patient's diet history reveals a significant lack of diversity, raising concerns about a potential deficiency in a specific nutrient. Given the clinical manifestations, which nutrient deficiency should the healthcare provider suspect as the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency can cause poor wound healing, erythematous pustular lesions (especially around the mouth), and persistent diarrhea. Recognizing these clinical signs is important for early diagnosis and intervention, as zinc plays a crucial role in skin health, immune function, and wound repair.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from a rural area with a history of consuming a diet predominantly consisting of grass peas presents to a neurological clinic. He reports experiencing muscle weakness and spasticity, particularly in his lower limbs. The healthcare provider suspects neuro-lathyrism, a condition associated with the consumption of Lathyrus sativus, which contains neurotoxic amino acids. Considering the need to manage his symptoms and potentially reverse the neurological damage, which vitamin should be considered for supplementation in his treatment plan?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ascorbic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuro-lathyrism is a neurological disorder caused by consuming grass peas containing neurotoxic compounds. Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) is important in both the prophylaxis and treatment of this condition, helping to reduce oxidative stress and neurological damage.
  • ➤ Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)

questions.text: A physician in India is navigating the complexities of providing medical care in a region characterized by a multitude of cultures and languages. Recognizing the impact of these factors on patient care is crucial. Which principle should guide the physician's approach to ensure an effective care in this diverse environment? Physician should emphasize on communication Treat patients regardless of patient’s perception Due emphasis should be given in patient cultural extent Leave communication to interpreter
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a diverse cultural and linguistic setting, physicians must prioritize effective communication and cultural sensitivity to provide patient-centered care. Taking the time to understand and respect the patient’s cultural context improves healthcare outcomes and fosters trust between the patient and the provider.
  • ➤ effective communication
  • ➤ cultural sensitivity

questions.text: In a community intervention study, researcher is exploring the inner workings of how individuals process their feelings and thoughts towards specific situations or other people. This internal perspective is crucial for understanding human behavior and social interactions. Which term best describes these inner subjective thoughts that an individual holds towards a person or a situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Belief

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A belief is an internal, subjective conviction or mental acceptance that influences how individuals perceive and process their thoughts and feelings toward a person or situation. Understanding the distinction between beliefs and other related concepts (like attitudes, opinions, and values) is key in behavioral studies.
  • ➤ belief

questions.text: In the context of assessing socio-economic status within a community, a public health researcher is utilizing the Kuppuswamy scale, a tool that categorizes families based on income, education, and occupation. This scale helps in understanding the social and economic dynamics of different groups. What score range on the Kuppuswamy scale is designated to classify a family as belonging to the upper socio-economic class?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 26–29

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kuppuswamy scale is a valuable tool in assessing socio-economic status, with scores between 26 and 29 indicating that a family belongs to the upper socio-economic class based on education, occupation, and income factors.
  • ➤ Kuppuswamy scale
  • ➤ 26 and 29
  • ➤ upper socio-economic class

questions.text: During a session on water treatment techniques, an expert highlights various method to ensure the safety and cleanliness of drinking water. Among the statements below, which one incorrectly describes an aspect of break point chlorination?

options.label: A
options.text: Free chlorine is released in water after break point chlorination

options.label: B
options.text: Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill bacteria, oxidize organic matter and neutralize ammonia

options.label: C
options.text: 1 ppm free chlorine should be present in water after break point has reached

options.label: D
options.text: Contact period of 1 hour is necessary

questions.correct_answer: C. 1 ppm free chlorine should be present in water after break point has reached
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 ppm free chlorine should be present in water after break point has reached

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After breakpoint chlorination, a minimum of 0.5 mg/L of free chlorine should be present in drinking water to ensure safety. This level differs in special cases such as swimming pools or post-disaster scenarios, where a higher concentration of 1 ppm may be required.
  • ➤ 0.5 mg/L of free chlorine

questions.text: In a study focusing on environmental conditions and their impact on thermal comfort, researchers are investigating the effects of low wind velocity and cooling power in various settings. To accurately measure these parameters, a specific instrument is required that can capture the nuanced changes in wind velocity and its cooling effect. Which of the following instruments is most suitable for this purpose, providing reliable data on low wind velocity and its cooling capacity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kata thermometer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kata thermometer is best suited for measuring low wind velocity in various environmental conditions. Understanding the instrument’s role in measuring air velocity is crucial when assessing thermal comfort, especially in environments where wind speed plays a role in cooling.
  • ➤ Kata thermometer
  • ➤ low wind velocity

questions.text: In a seminar focused on sanitation solutions for temporary settlements, such as refugee camps or construction sites, the topic of appropriate latrine options is discussed. While many latrine types are suitable for short-term use due to their simplicity and minimal environmental impact, one option is generally considered too complex and permanent for such scenarios. Which of the following latrine types is not typically recommended for camps and temporary use due to its more permanent nature and complexity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Septic tank

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The septic tank is not recommended for temporary use because it is a more permanent, complex solution requiring substantial infrastructure. The ideal retention period for wastewater in a septic tank is 24 hours , a key point to remember when considering long-term sanitation solutions.
  • ➤ septic tank
  • ➤ 24 hours

questions.text: According to safety regulations, what is the maximum permissible dose of man-made radiation that an individual should not exceed in a year to avoid adverse health effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5 rads per year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maximum permissible dose of man-made radiation that an individual can be exposed to safely in a year is 5 rads . This limit is critical for ensuring health and safety in environments where radiation exposure is possible.
  • ➤ man-made radiation
  • ➤ 5 rads

questions.text: In efforts to control mosquito populations and prevent the spread of mosquito-borne diseases, various methods are employed to target the larval stage of mosquitoes. Among the following options, identify the one that is not used as an anti-larval measure in mosquito control programs:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pyrethrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyrethrum is primarily used to control adult mosquitoes by acting as a nerve poison, whereas other methods such as intermittent irrigation, Paris green, and Gambusia affinis are effective anti-larval measures targeting the larval stage of mosquitoes to prevent their maturation and reduce overall mosquito populations.
  • ➤ Pyrethrum
  • ➤ anti-larval measures

questions.text: Based on the list provided, identify which of the following diseases are transmitted by mosquitoes: Yellow fever Q fever Chikungunya fever Relapsing fever Japanese encephalitis Sleeping sickness
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 3, and 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mosquitoes are vectors for a variety of diseases, including Yellow fever , Chikungunya , and Japanese encephalitis , but they do not transmit diseases such as Q fever , Relapsing fever , or Sleeping sickness . Understanding the vectors involved in disease transmission is key to controlling the spread of these infections.
  • ➤ Yellow fever
  • ➤ Chikungunya
  • ➤ Japanese encephalitis
  • ➤ Q fever
  • ➤ Relapsing fever
  • ➤ Sleeping sickness

questions.text: A 27-year-old construction worker visits an otolaryngologist after experiencing a sudden loss of hearing following an incident at a demolition site. The patient reports being in close proximity to a controlled explosion without adequate ear protection. The physician suspects a rupture of the tympanic membrane due to the acute exposure to an intense sound wave. Considering the potential for permanent hearing damage, what is the minimum level of sound intensity that is likely to cause such an injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 160 dB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The minimum sound intensity likely to cause tympanic membrane rupture is approximately 160 dB . Understanding the risks associated with high-intensity sounds, especially in occupational environments, is essential for preventing permanent hearing damage.
  • ➤ minimum sound intensity
  • ➤ 160 dB

questions.text: In a hospital setting, a healthcare professional is calibrating blood pressure equipment when a mercury sphygmomanometer accidentally breaks, leading to a mercury spill on the floor. This incident requires immediate attention to prevent mercury vapor exposure, which can be harmful to health. In addressing this spill, what would be the most appropriate and safe method for the healthcare professional to follow in cleaning up the spilled mercury?

options.label: A
options.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain

options.label: B
options.text: Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

options.label: C
options.text: Collect and throw outside in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.correct_answer: B. Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mercury spills should be handled carefully using tools like paper or cardboard to collect the droplets, and the spill area should be decontaminated with sodium thiosulphate . Understanding the correct procedures for handling hazardous materials, especially in healthcare settings, is crucial for ensuring safety and preventing toxic exposure.
  • ➤ sodium thiosulphate

questions.text: After a region experiences a significant earthquake, the local government undertakes a review of the existing infrastructure's resilience to such natural disasters. As a result, they decide to implement new building codes that mandate the construction of earthquake-resistant structures. This proactive measure is aimed at reducing the impact of future seismic events on the community. Within the framework of disaster management, which phase does the introduction of these new building codes best represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Responding to the immediate aftermath of the disaster.

options.label: B
options.text: Rebuilding the physical structures that were destroyed.

options.label: C
options.text: Restoring the community to its pre-disaster conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: Taking measures to lessen the effects of future disasters.

questions.correct_answer: D. Taking measures to lessen the effects of future disasters.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Taking measures to lessen the effects of future disasters.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Disaster mitigation involves taking measures to reduce the impact of future disasters, such as implementing earthquake-resistant building codes. Understanding the various phases of disaster management—preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation—helps in planning effectively to safeguard communities against future risks.
  • ➤ Disaster mitigation

questions.text: In a lecture, Professor discusses various forms of pneumoconiosis, each associated with specific clinical disorders due to long-term exposure to different inhaled particulates. The students are tasked with matching each type of pneumoconiosis to its corresponding clinical manifestation to better understand the relationship between occupational exposures and respiratory health outcomes. Match the following types of pneumoconiosis with their most closely associated clinical disorders: Pneumoconiosis: Asbestosis Silicosis Coal workers’ pneumoconiosis Bagassosis Clinical associations: Caplan’s syndrome Mesothelioma and pleural effusions, predominantly in the lower lobes Acute diffuse bronchiolitis "Crazy paving" pattern on High-Resolution Computed Tomography (HRCT)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Each form of pneumoconiosis has distinct clinical associations depending on the inhaled particulate and the nature of the disease. For example, asbestosis is linked to mesothelioma , silicosis to the crazy paving pattern on HRCT , coal workers’ pneumoconiosis to Caplan's syndrome , and bagassosis to acute diffuse bronchiolitis . Recognizing these associations is important for diagnosing and managing occupational lung diseases.
  • ➤ pneumoconiosis
  • ➤ asbestosis
  • ➤ mesothelioma
  • ➤ silicosis
  • ➤ crazy paving pattern on HRCT
  • ➤ coal workers’ pneumoconiosis
  • ➤ Caplan's syndrome
  • ➤ bagassosis
  • ➤ acute diffuse bronchiolitis

questions.text: At a global health summit, a keynote speaker reflects on groundbreaking projects that have shaped modern medicine. Among these, the Human Genome Project stands out for its ambitious scope. This initiative, once considered a moonshot. What was the primary goal of the Human Genome Project?

options.label: A
options.text: To introduce a specific gene sequence into cells to alter their function.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop novel diagnostic methods, including the use of restriction enzymes.

options.label: C
options.text: To identify all the genes and determine the sequence of the base pairs that make up human DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide empirical evidence supporting the Hardy-Weinberg Law in human populations.

questions.correct_answer: C. To identify all the genes and determine the sequence of the base pairs that make up human DNA.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) To identify all the genes and determine the sequence of the base pairs that make up human DNA.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Human Genome Project aimed to identify all the genes in human DNA and determine the complete sequence of the base pairs that make up the human genome. This knowledge has revolutionized the field of genetics and medicine, enabling advancements in diagnostics, therapeutics, and understanding human biology.
  • ➤ Human Genome Project

questions.text: In an educational setting, various formats are utilized to facilitate learning and information exchange. These methods range from highly interactive sessions to more traditional, didactic approaches. Among the options listed, which one is typically characterized by a one-way flow of information rather than a two-way communication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lecture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lecture is a one-way communication format where the speaker delivers information to the audience, unlike more interactive formats such as symposiums, panel discussions, and workshops, which encourage two-way communication. Understanding the different learning formats helps in selecting the most appropriate method for specific educational goals.
  • ➤ lecture

questions.text: During a workshop on program evaluation, a facilitator emphasizes the importance of various elements that contribute to a thorough assessment of any public health initiative. These elements are critical for understanding the program's impact, its alignment with goals, and its reception among the target population. However, one of the listed options is not typically considered a direct element of program evaluation. Which of the following does not belong to the core elements of evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Repeatability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When evaluating a public health program, key elements include relevance , acceptability , accessibility, adequacy , effectiveness , efficiency , and impact . Repeatability is not typically part of program evaluation but is more relevant in experimental research.
  • ➤ relevance
  • ➤ acceptability
  • ➤ accessibility, adequacy
  • ➤ effectiveness
  • ➤ efficiency
  • ➤ impact
  • ➤ Repeatability

questions.text: In a public health course, students are tasked with understanding the historical context and contributions of various health committees in India to the country's healthcare system. These committees have played pivotal roles in shaping policies, planning, and the delivery of healthcare services across the nation. The assignment involves matching each committee to its primary focus or achievement as described. Match the following names of health committees with their corresponding contributions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-I, B-IV, C-III, D-II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The historical contributions of key health committees in India, such as the Bhore Committee (Health Survey & Development) , Mudaliar Committee (Health Survey & Planning) , Jungalwallah Committee (Integration of Health Services) , and Kartar Singh Committee (Multipurpose Workers) , is crucial in recognizing how these committees shaped India's healthcare policies and services.
  • ➤ Bhore Committee (Health Survey & Development)
  • ➤ Mudaliar Committee (Health Survey & Planning)
  • ➤ Jungalwallah Committee (Integration of Health Services)
  • ➤ Kartar Singh Committee (Multipurpose Workers)

questions.text: In a public health lecture on bioterrorism, the instructor discusses the categorization of biological agents based on their threat level and potential for public health impact. The students are presented with a scenario where they must identify the incorrect statement regarding the classification system used by health authorities to prioritize agents for research and preparedness. The classifications are designed to guide the response to a bioterrorism event. Which of the following statements about the categories of bioterrorism agents does not accurately reflect the established categorization?

options.label: A
options.text: Category A comprises agents with the highest priority due to their ease of transmission and high mortality rates.

options.label: B
options.text: Category B includes agents that are moderately easy to disseminate and result in moderate morbidity rates.

options.label: C
options.text: Category C encompasses emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass spread in the future.

options.label: D
options.text: Category D is a recognized classification for agents known for their extreme lethality.

questions.correct_answer: D. Category D is a recognized classification for agents known for their extreme lethality.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Category D is a recognized classification for agents known for their extreme lethality.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bioterrorism agents are classified into three categories (A, B, C) based on their potential impact on public health, ease of transmission, and mortality rates. Understanding these classifications is crucial for preparedness and response in public health emergencies related to bioterrorism.
  • ➤ three categories (A, B, C)

questions.text: In a program aimed at improving nutrition in schools, one initiative involves providing seeds and manure to help schools grow their own food. This effort is part of a broader strategy to educate children on nutrition and sustainable farming. Which organization is known for supporting such school health services?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) UNICEF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ UNICEF plays a key role in promoting school health services, including initiatives that teach children about nutrition and sustainability through practical projects like school gardens. Understanding the specific contributions of different global organizations can help in identifying their roles in public health and education initiatives.
  • ➤ UNICEF

questions.text: In a medical training session on emergency care, the instructor introduces the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) as a tool for assessing a patient's level of consciousness following head injury. What type of scale is the GCS classified as in terms of data measurement?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ordinal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is an ordinal scale , used to rank levels of consciousness after head injury. Understanding how different scales of measurement work is crucial for appropriate data collection and interpretation in clinical settings.
  • ➤ Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)
  • ➤ ordinal scale

questions.text: A research team is analyzing a large dataset to determine if it follows a normal distribution before applying parametric statistical tests. They utilize several methods to assess the normality of the data visually and statistically. Which of the following mentioned methods, are appropriate for testing the normalcy of their data? Histogram Box and whisker plot Shapiro wilk test Q-Q plot
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To assess the normalcy of data , both visual methods (such as histograms, box plots, and Q-Q plots) and statistical tests (like the Shapiro-Wilk test) are commonly used. Combining these methods provides a comprehensive assessment of data distribution.
  • ➤ normalcy of data
  • ➤ visual methods
  • ➤ statistical tests
